description: Uncertain. Perhaps a contraction from Dutch kajuit (“cabin”).

entries.meaning: (nautical) A cabin, for the use of the captain, in the after part of a sailing ship under the poop deck.
examples: Being summoned to the cuddy to breakfast, I had not been there five minutes when I turned deadly sick, was obliged to retire to my cot  […] .

entries.meaning: (Scotland, Durham, Northumbria, historical) A donkey, especially one driven by a huckster or greengrocer.
examples: folk said the cuddy had bided so long with Pooty that whenever it opened its mouth to give a bit bray it started to stutter.

entries.meaning: (UK, mining) A pony that works in a mine.

examples: It cost more tricks and trouble, by half, Than it takes to exhibit a six-legged calf To a boothful of country cuddies.

entries.meaning: A lever mounted on a tripod for lifting stones, leveling up railroad ties, etc..

description: From Scots cuddie; compare Gaelic cudaig, cudainn, or English cuttlefish, or cod.
